Problem:
Consider a system governed by the linear operator equation \\(Lx = \lambda x\\). Analyze how utilizing a transformation \\(T(x) = e^{i\theta}x\\), where \\(i\\) is the imaginary unit and \\(\theta\\) a constant, affects the system over a time-scale \\(t\\).

If \\(T(x)\\) is applied to a function \\(x_0\\) at t = 0, and then allowed to evolve under \\(Lx = \lambda x\\) without further intervention, will \\(x(t)\\) at t = T be the same as if \\(x_0\\) was directly evolved to t = T under \\(Lx = \lambda x\\)?
Explanation: The transformation \\(T(x) = e^{i\theta}x\\) only applies a phase shift in the complex plane that does not affect the evolution of the eigenfunctions of L. Since they are only scaled by \\(e^{i\theta}\\), the evolution under the operator remains unaffected, preserving the trajectory.
